guide.introduction: Reproducing digital artwork in embroidery isn't hard if you follow these simple steps. I'll show you how using the fffffatlab text.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Reproducing digital artwork in embroidery isn't hard if you follow these simple steps. I'll show you how using the fffffatlab text.

Relevant parts
  • Fabric
  • Embroidery needle
  • Paper
  • Conte crayon
Tools
  • Ballpoint pen
  • Embroidery hoop
  • Sewing machine

lines.text: If you're using a light-colored fabric, you may be able to trace directly on the fabric. In this case, I'm using a very opaque canvas fabric, so I had to first trace the design on paper, directly from my computer screen.
lines.text_raw: If you're using a light-colored fabric, you may be able to trace directly on the fabric. In this case, I'm using a very opaque canvas fabric, so I had to first trace the design on paper, directly from my computer screen.

lines.text: Don't use a drawing implement that requires too much pressure or that will bleed through onto your monitor. A regular ballpoint pen works just fine.
lines.text_raw: Don't use a drawing implement that requires too much pressure or that will bleed through onto your monitor. A regular ballpoint pen works just fine.

lines.text: If you traced your design directly onto your fabric, skip this step.
lines.text_raw: If you traced your design directly onto your fabric, skip this step.

lines.text: Turn your paper template over and apply chalk or conti crayon to the back (in a color that will be visible on your fabric).
lines.text_raw: Turn your paper template over and apply chalk or conti crayon to the back (in a color that will be visible on your fabric).

lines.text: Shake off the dust and place the paper template on your fabric.
lines.text_raw: Shake off the dust and place the paper template on your fabric.

lines.text: Trace over the design with a dull pencil or ballpoint pen, transferring the lines of the design onto your fabric.
lines.text_raw: Trace over the design with a dull pencil or ballpoint pen, transferring the lines of the design onto your fabric.

lines.text: Be careful not to touch it too much after this, as the chalk will rub off with your touch.
lines.text_raw: Be careful not to touch it too much after this, as the chalk will rub off with your touch.

lines.text: Stretch your fabric in your embroidery hoop.
lines.text_raw: Stretch your fabric in your embroidery hoop.

lines.text: Select your floss color and get started.
lines.text_raw: Select your floss color and get started.

lines.text: Use whatever stitches you feel are appropriate, and don't be afraid to experiment. I used the satin stitch for these.
lines.text_raw: Use whatever stitches you feel are appropriate, and don't be afraid to experiment. I used the satin stitch for these.

lines.text: It may be helpful to keep your reference image up on your monitor so you can keep track of small details that might have been lost in the tracing transfer.
lines.text_raw: It may be helpful to keep your reference image up on your monitor so you can keep track of small details that might have been lost in the tracing transfer.

lines.text: When finished, take your fabric out of the hoop and shake off any remaining chalk.
lines.text_raw: When finished, take your fabric out of the hoop and shake off any remaining chalk.

lines.text: Iron out the creases from the hoop.
lines.text_raw: Iron out the creases from the hoop.

lines.text: This step is optional, but gives a nice finished look to your patch.
lines.text_raw: This step is optional, but gives a nice finished look to your patch.

lines.text: Cut a rectangle of your backing fabric with about a 3/8" border seam allowance all around your patch.
lines.text_raw: Cut a rectangle of your backing fabric with about a 3/8" border seam allowance all around your patch.

lines.text: Press in a 1/4" fold on all sides. Trim the corners at a 45° angle passing through the intersection of the two ironed creases.
lines.text_raw: Press in a 1/4" fold on all sides. Trim the corners at a 45° angle passing through the intersection of the two ironed creases.

lines.text: Iron in another 1/4" fold, turning under the first fold you made.
lines.text_raw: Iron in another 1/4" fold, turning under the first fold you made.

lines.text: Press in the corners so that the edge of the crease intersects the new corner intersecting folds, then press in the sides again.
lines.text_raw: Press in the corners so that the edge of the crease intersects the new corner intersecting folds, then press in the sides again.

lines.text: You should end up with nice mitered corners.
lines.text_raw: You should end up with nice mitered corners.

lines.text: Place the patch inside this frame and topstitch around all edges for a nice complete patch.
lines.text_raw: Place the patch inside this frame and topstitch around all edges for a nice complete patch.
